channel.title: Posts on Kevin Schaul
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Kevin Schaul

item.title: Follow a mile-by-mile map of the total solar eclipse
Recently
These fake images reveeal how AI amplifies our worst sterotypes
Writing a bad chess engine
item.description: To stay sharp while on parental leave, I’ve been toying around with writing a chess engine. A bad one. I am truly awful at chess. I know how the pieces are allowed to move, but that’s it. If I am lucky enough to find myself ahead in an endgame, you can just move around randomly. I’ll never figure out how to checkmate you. But writing a program to play chess better than I can sounds … pretty doable?

item.title: avoid-overlap: Utilities for chart-makers to avoid text overlaps in their graphics
item.description: I’ve been working on a library to help chart-makers avoid text overlaps in their graphics, and it’s finally in a place worth sharing. Check it out on GitHub or in action at two of my recent graphics. Labeling charts, maps and other graphics is more art than science, but there are some general rules we can follow to achieve good results programmatically. This library provides two label-avoidance techniques: nudge and choices.

item.title: See how AI got so good, so fast
How we analyzed the websites in a commonly used AI training dataset
item.description: My colleagues and I recently published this analysis of 15 million websites in a commonly used AI training dataset. Here’s a little bit about how we did it. Allen Institute researchers kindly provided us with the top 1,000 domains in Googleâ€™s C4 dataset. But that was just 8% of tokens, hardly representative. So they then pulled all 15.7M domains. We planned to categorize the top 1,000 websites by hand, but all 15.

item.title: See the websites that make AI like ChatGPT sound so smart
Feedmaker: Quickly generate an RSS feed from any website
item.description: I’ve been diverting much of my web browsing away from social media and towards RSS feeds, but there are so many sites that don’t offer the feeds for the content I care about. Today I’m sharing a side project called Feedmaker (Source on GitHub). It’s a service that lets you generate RSS feeds from websites in next to no time. Just figure out a couple CSS selectors and pass them as URL parameters.
